journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering

title-group.article-title: Application of self-learning evolutionary algorithm for optimal design of a porous polymethylmethacrylate scaffold fabricated by laser drilling process

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Babol University of Technology, Babol, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Alireza Fathi, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Babol University of Technology, Babol, Iran. Email: fathi@nit.ac.ir

abstract.p: Fabrication of scaffolds that closely mimic the biomechanical properties of the surrounding bone is one of the main issues in designing an orthopedic implant. This study is aimed to develop an optimal predefined three-dimensional polymethylmethacrylate scaffold as a potential bone substitute via laser drilling technique, which is a novel method of fabricating bone scaffold. To achieve this goal, using the obtained experimental data, the authors have tuned an adaptive neuro fuzzy inference system, which predicts the hole diameter and its depth as two process outputs for any given values of laser power and laser irradiation time. In addition to this adaptive neuro fuzzy inference system model, some experimental models were also proposed to estimate the scaffold porosity and the mechanical strength regarding the drilled hole geometry. To design an optimal scaffold with the highest amount of strength and porosity, a Pareto-based self-learning evolutionary algorithm called SOPEA was proposed. To enhance its ability in finding the optimal Pareto front, it was equipped with the adaptive self-organizing map. Based on the obtained Pareto front, a trade-off has been made in order to find a solution that yields deliberate operational properties. The scaffold morphology was observed by scanning electron microscopy images and its mechanical property was determined using a compressive test. The versatility provided by this technique allows the fabrication of scaffolds with controllable amount of porosity, pore size, and mechanical properties while providing fully interconnected channel network. The results also indicate that the proposed model predicts the process outputs with acceptable accuracy and the proposed optimization algorithm is able to find the optimal solution effectively.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A designed scaffold for tissue-engineering applications should be three-dimensional (3D), highly porous and internally interconnected to support cell attachment as well as proliferation.1 Also they should have sufficient structural integrity matching the mechanical properties of native tissue. Most of the available scaffold fabrication methods, such as solvent casting, fiber bonding, phase separation, gas induced foaming, and salt leaching, are either limited to producing scaffolds with simple geometry, or depend on indirect casting method for scaffold fabrication.2–5 These traditional scaffold fabrication methods result in structures of random internal architecture and have great variation from part to part. Solid free-form fabrication (SFF) techniques have attracted a lot attention in recent years for the reason that these kind of methods enable design and fabrication of anatomically shaped scaffolds with varying internal architectures, thereby allowing precise control over pore size, porosity, permeability, and stiffness. Control over these characteristics may enhance cell infiltration and mass transport of nutrients and metabolic waste throughout the scaffold.6,7 In spite of their advantages, there are still some limitations in using SFF methods. Some of the SFF methods are limited to the type of the material. In some indirect SFF methods, the fabricated parts experience dimensional changes or may inherit errors and defects from the molding process such as cracks.8

The development of laser-assisted surface micro-patterning, modification and micro-drilling of biomaterials especially polymers has thus taken a considerable interest in recent times. Wilhelm Pfleging et al.9 investigated laser-assisted patterning and modification of polystyrene (PS) with respect to applications in micro-fluidics and cell culture. Aguilar et al.10 made use of pulsed-laser micromachining to generate high-resolution micro-patterns on biodegradable thin film polymers using a Ti-sapphire femtosecond pulsed laser and ArF excimer UV laser. Laser drilling makes it possible to machine very small holes and allows precise size control. Rosen et al.11 described laser drilling of holes in silicon chips for capturing nerve cell fibers. Results showed that these devices have potential use in nerve repair devices, nerve grafts, and prosthesis–nerve interfaces. Man et al.12 investigated laser surface micro-drilling of Ti for enhancing fixation of dental implants and growth of bone cells deep into the hole for better fixation of metallic implants.

In order to generate drilled holes with desired geometry, the laser drilling process should be modeled. Yilbas13,14 studied laser percussion drilling. He developed statistical models and expressed the effects of laser parameters such as pulse time and pulse power on specifications of the holes geometry. Artificial intelligence methodologies are other approaches that are widely used to control, optimize and model such processes. Until now, efforts have been made to model the laser drilling process for facilitating the scaffold fabrication procedure. Nakhjavani et al.15 employed neural network to model the laser percussion drilling process. They used mild steel sheets as work pieces. Chaiyaratana and Zalzala16 used several neural network models to reduce friction. They also utilized genetic algorithm (GA) to achieve the best neural network model. Ghoreishi and Nakhjavani17 optimized the effective factors in geometrical specifications of laser percussion drilled hole using generalized regression neural network (GRNN) and GA.

The objective of this study is to develop a methodology for finding the optimal fabrication process parameters of a predefined 3D poly(methylmethacrylate) scaffold fabricated by laser drilling technique. To achieve this goal, first an experimental fuzzy based model is applied to predict the drilled hole geometrical characteristics and then using a Pareto based self learning evolutionary algorithm called SOPEA, the optimal process parameters are extracted.

sec.title: Problem definition
sec.p:
A schematic illustration of the laser drilling process is shown in Figure 1. The experiments were conducted using a 100 W carbon dioxide (CO2) laser (made by Fanavaran Laser Sahand Company). The laser system was integrated with a 2-axis CNC table and a computer controlled shutter to control the laser on/off state. Argon gas with a 3.2 bar pressure was used to shield the processing zone and to protect the optical lens. Figure 1.
Configuration of laser drilling setup.

In order to fabricate a 3D porous scaffold, arrays of through holes were drilled on all sides of a cubic shape bulk PMMA. Figure 2 illustrates a CAD model of the proposed scaffold. According to this figure, if the holes intersect each other, a fully interconnected channel network is produced. The holes center distance (δL) and the hole diameter are two key process parameters that have the greatest effect on the scaffold properties. Large center distance will result a low porous scaffold with a high mechanical strength while low center distance will produce a high porous and low strength scaffold. The hole diameter has a similar behavior with some more complexity. To design an optimal scaffold from its porosity and its mechanical strength aspects, these two process parameters should be determined carefully. Figure 2.
Schematic model of the scaffold.

Finding the optimal process parameters needs having a precise model for the process which relates the process inputs and outputs. In this case the process inputs are laser power, holes center distance and laser irradiation time, while the process outputs are scaffold porosity, scaffold mechanical strength and the manufacturing time. Figure 3 shows the structure of the proposed model for the process. According to this figure, this model includes an ANFIS sub-model and three numerical/experimental models. Based on the input values, the model tries to estimate three different outputs i.e. manufacturing time, porosity and mechanical strength. In the first step, according to the depicted block diagram the ANFIS model is applied to predict the hole diameter (D) and depth of drilled holes (H). In the second step, three parameters namely depth of drilled hole (H), hole diameter (D) and center distance (δL) are used to calculate the amount of porosity and in the third step, the compressive strength as a function of porosity is determined. The laser power (P) and laser irradiation time (t) were considered as the inputs to the ANFIS model in order to predict the average hole diameter and the hole depth. The ANFIS model was trained using the experimental data. Figure 3.
Block diagram of the laser drilling process.

Since in this study, the fabricated scaffold has a regular network, the scaffold porosity can be estimated precisely by calculating the amount of removed material and its initial volume. Assuming a fully interconnected network, the porosity of a cubic scaffold is calculated as the follows (1)Vbulk=L3
(2)Vremoved=N3AH-23N3*Aintrsect
(3)N=LδL
(4)H=min (H,L )
(5)Porosity=VremovedVbalk*100 where L is the cubic edge length, N is number of holes row in each dimension, A is the hole cross section, H is the hole length, and Aintersect is the intersection volume of three holes from different side.

Manufacturing time depends on the number of drilled holes and the laser irradiation time for each hole. This time can be calculated according to the following equation (6)manufacturing time=N3* irradiation time The remaining part of the proposed model is the mechanical strength submodel. Since the mechanical strength depends entirely on the porosity, in this study an experimental model is developed. The proposed model is a black-box model which is trained using the obtained experimental data. To do this, several specimens with different porosity are used for compressive test. The resulted data and the model are described in the next sections.

sec.title: Adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system
sec.p: In this paper, the authors applied two neuro-fuzzy systems to predict the average hole diameter and the depth of drilled hole due to the variation of laser power and laser irradiation time. Neuro-fuzzy system is a hybrid modeling frame work, which is the result of combination of artificial neural network (ANN) and fuzzy logic. This hybrid model was developed to overcome the disadvantages of both techniques. In neuro-fuzzy system, the ANN is used to tune the membership function of fuzzy systems.18 The synaptic weights of ANN with the aid of fuzzy rules provide deep insight into the neural network. Besides, the nonlinear membership of neuro-fuzzy approach show important contribution in decrementing the implementation cost and reduction of rule based and the consuming memory. So, it is obvious that combination of ANN and fuzzy system handles limitations and suggests an acceptable data mining procedure for solving critical and complex engineering systems with chaotic behavior. Adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) is one of the most well-known modeling tools that employed the ANN and fuzzy system simultaneously. It uses empirical input/output data sets for modeling the behavior of systems. ANFIS is constructed from fuzzy inference system (FIS). Mandani-type19 and Takagi-Sugeno-Kang-type (TSK).20,21 of FIS are the most applicable systems for constructing an ANFIS structure. TSK model is simpler to identify because it needs less rules and also it uses some well-known learning methods like back-propagation (BP) algorithm. In this article, a hybrid learning algorithm that is the combination of BP and least-squares (LS) is applied to adjust the membership functions parameters in TSK fuzzy system. The characteristics of ANFIS network is scrutinized in the Appendix.

sec.title: Self-organizing Pareto-based evolutionary algorithm (SOPEA)
sec.p:
Multi-objective optimization is at the heart of most real world decision-making tasks in which a choice must be made between several alternatives corresponding to conflicting objectives. In such cases, it is not feasible to obtain an ideal optimum solution since all the objectives are equally significant. Hence, a set of non-dominated solutions may be produced to trade-off among different objectives. The methods that produce these sets of solutions are conventionally called Pareto-based algorithm. The main concepts of this strategy were first developed by the engineer/economist Vilfredo Pareto.22,23 According to his definition a solution is Pareto-optimal if it is dominated by no other solution, is superior at least in case of one objective function value, and is equal to or superior than other objective function values. The Pareto optimal solutions are rather a class of solutions, forming a surface in objective function space, which is generally called Pareto front. Multi-objective hybrid evolutionary-learning methodologies are one of the most important types of Pareto-based algorithms. Application of hybrid evolutionary-learning algorithm began by Michalski’s24 researches who hired machine learning technique and evolutionary algorithm to generate new population. These types of algorithms are simply called learnable evolutionary models (LEMs). After that many researchers focused on this concept and developed new models and improvements. Ammor and Rettinger25 applied self-organizing map, sometimes known as Kohonen map, (SOM) to improve diversity and avoiding fast convergence. SOM approximates the probability of density of input data distribution. Kobuta et al.26 developed SOM for the reproduction of new seeds in GA. In this article, an adaptive SOM with concise mechanism has been combined with Pareto-based EA to detect the features of obtained non-dominated solutions in current optimal Pareto front as on-line input data. Figure 4 illustrates the schematic illustration of SOM contribution in finding further non-dominated solutions. The results show that this peculiar unsupervised network can play an important role in finding an intense front with acceptable diversification. Along with the SOM network, the proposed SOPEA is composed of some well-known evolutionary operators i.e. tournament selection, fast and elitism non-dominated sorting27 and an external archive. In the following subparts, the main features of proposed SOM network, external archive and the controlling parameters are described. Eventually, steps required for implementing SOPEA is given more closely. Figure 4.
Schematic flowchart of SPOEA.

sec.title: Adaptive SOM with conscience mechanism
sec.p: In this section, an adaptive SOM with a gradient learning rule and concise mechanism will be summarized briefly. Adaptive SOM, which was first proposed by Kohonen,28 is a type of unsupervised ANN that automatically adapts the learning rate and neighborhood function of neuron weights independently. One of its major applications is to normalize all distance calculations between any input vector (non-dominated solutions) and the neuron’s weight vector by providing a suitable topological ordering for input distribution. Generally, a SOM network with concise mechanism uses the following learning rule (7)Wj n+1 (t )=Wj n (t )+yj (t )·hj (n )· (Ri n (t )-Wj n (t ) ),t=1,2,…,T where t is sub-generation in SOM network and n represents the SOPEA generation number. yj (t ) is a control parameter that leads weight vectors to a non-dominated solution, which was transferred from the external archive to the network as an on-line input. In other word if the input’s fitness value fR, which is a non-dominated solution, is lower than fWj(n) then yj (t )=1 and neuron center moves toward the non-dominated solution (networks input) otherwise yj (t )=0 and neuron center does not approach to the solution. This can mathematically expressed as (8)yj (t )= {1ifR (t )dominateWj(t)0otherwise Wj n+1 (t ) refers to updated weight vector and Wj n (t ) is the old weight vector. Ri n-Wj n represents the distance between input vectors where Ri n is the i-th non-dominate solution in n-th generation. The learning rate which is a descending function is defined as following (9)hj (t+1 )=hj (t )+α (f (1sf.sl (t )Rj n (t )-Wj n (t ) ) ) The learning rate parameter hj (0 ) should be initialized with a value close to unity. α obtains any arbitrary value between 0 and 1. sf is a descending constant and should be set based on the problem condition. In this article, we set sf=1000. Function f(.) should be designed in a manner that the following criteria is satisfied appropriately
f (0 )=0, 0≤f (z )≤1, and df(z)dz≥0 for positive values of z.
In this article f (z ) is set as (10)f (z )=1-1/1+z

Scaling value sl for an n dimensional input is adjusted using the following equations (11)sl (t+1 )= (∑i=1 nEk i (t+1 )n-i(-1)i+1 )+,k=1
(12)Ek i (t+1 )=Ek i (t )+μi (Rk i (t )-Ek i (t ) ) where i represents the number of variable in each solution. Ek i (0 ) is initialized with some small random values. Figure 5(a) depicts the scheme of neurons updating in SOM grid. Figure 5.
(a) Gradual movement of Neurons in a defined topological neighborhood of data center (Non-dominated solution), (b) Schematic of Conscience mechanism.

Concise mechanism is applied in order to revive the dead units (weights) in neuron center. The schematic illustration of this procedure is visualized in Figure 5(b). Dead unit is a term that refers to weights with a trivial chance of learning and adaptation during the progress. The policy of repairing these units is often called concise mechanism. In this paper a simple well-known mechanism is utilized which tunes the bios of node (neuron) by following formula (13)bi (t+1 )= {0.8bi (t )orbi (t )-0.3
(14)hj (t+1 )=hj (t )+α (f (1sf·sl (t )Rj n (t )-Wj n (t ) ) )

sec.title: External archive
sec.p: SOPEA is equipped with an external archive that collects the gained non-dominated solutions. This technique reduces the computational complexity when the algorithm derives to high number of non-dominated solutions since its task is just to retain the obtained non-dominated solutions in each generation. Besides, defining an external archive provides some elitism by preserving non-dominated solutions. The feedback from applying this policy illustrates that the speed of algorithm does not decline so much in higher number of non-dominated solutions.

sec.title: Control parameters
sec.p:
Basically, SOPEA possessed a limited number of controlling parameters which are expressed in Table 1. Table 1.
SOPEA control parameters.
Parameters Spans Application
Pmut [0,1] Controlling the mutation probability
Ps arbitrary SSLPSA’s population size
ξ [0,1] the speed and robustness in SOPEA
n arbitrary Number of generations
T arbitrary Number of SOM network epochs
Nu arbitrary Number of neurons in each network center
sf [500,1500] Descending constants in SOM learning algorithm
α,μ [0,1] Descending constants in SOM learning algorithm

sec.title: SOPEA structure
sec.p:
Following steps are to be made for implementing SOPEA algorithm:
Step 0: Define SOPEA’s initial parameters.
Step 1: Define the number of tribes.
Step 2: Randomly generate Ps solution for the initial population P1.
Step 3: Evaluate the fitness of solutions.
Step 4: Perform the tournament selection in population and save them as parents.
Step 5: Execute the reproduction process between parents and save the off-springs in mating pool.
Step 6: Perform the mutation in the current population.
Step 7: Rank the obtained solutions base on fast and elitism non-dominated sorting procedure and save them in the Archive.
Step 8: Thrust the obtained non-dominated solutions (as desire data centers) in SOM grid.
Step 9: Define random weight vectors for SOM grid’s unit center (Nu) in a uniform stochastic distribution manner spanning to problem solution space.
Step 10: Evaluate the fitness of weight vectors.
Step 11: Train the weight vectors in SOM center (Wj n,j=1,2,…,Nu) using obtained non-dominate solutions (non-dominated chromosomes) in the current n-th generation.
Step 12: Generate new weight vectorWj n+1.
Step 13: Move the SOM grid’s mobile units toward non-dominance features. If the new weights dominated old ones, replace old ones with new ones, otherwise, save the new non-dominate weights in the designed external archive.
Step 14: If the stopping criterion is satisfied, go to step 15, otherwise go to step 3.
Step 15: The solutions which are recorded in the external archive are considered as the final solutions.
Step 16: Stop.

sec.title: Modeling the hole diameter and depth of drilled hole
sec.p:
Experiments were conducted to investigate the influence of laser power and laser irradiation time on the hole entrance diameter, hole exit diameter, and depth of drilled hole. Each experiment was repeated for five times, and an average value of responses was obtained. The hole diameter and its depth were measured using an optical microscope and a caliper respectively. Average hole diameter is the mean value of entrance hole diameter and the exit hole diameter. The laser beam focal point was set on the material surface. The spot diameter of the laser beam was 300 µm. The laser power and the laser irradiation time were set at five levels 12, 19, 31, 38, and 58 W and 300, 400, 500, 600, and 700 ms, respectively. Hole diameter range of 340–700 µm and hole depth range of 3–17.1 mm were attained. The PMMA sheet thickness was 10 mm. Each experiment was repeated five times, and the average value of each test was obtained as the resulted value. Based on the obtained experimental data, the proposed models were trained. The ANFIS model input parameters include laser power and laser irradiation time and its outputs include the average hole diameter and hole depth. Definition of proper fuzzy membership functions and the appropriate number of required rules are two major steps in applying ANFIS. To find the efficient structure of ANFIS, several networks with different membership functions were designed. For training these networks two stopping criteria were set. These criteria are error goal of 0.01 and number of 50 epochs. In other words, the training procedure terminated when the RMS reached to 0.01 or the epochs exceed from 50. After checking all of the designed ANFISs, the network that revealed optimum accuracy in anticipation of test data was selected. The correlation of ANFIS’s output and the experimental data are shown in Figure 6. Figure 6.
The correlation of the experimental data and the ANFIS prediction in training and test phase.

It can be seen that the applied ANFIS show acceptable result in both training and testing phases. The experimental and predicted values of the average hole diameter and hole depth are given in Table 2. Table 2.
Comparison of experimental data with predicted value for hole diameter and depth.
No. Laser power (W) (×3.86) Time (ms) Experimental data for D (µm) ANFIS prediction for D (µm) Experimental data for H (µm) ANFIS prediction for H (µm)
1. 3 700 381.3131 381.3075 3.0000 2.9998
2. 5 700 530.1670 530.1681 10.1000 10.1000
3. 15 700 613.0055 613.0055 17.1000 16.8999
4. 15 600 610.2443 610.2442 15.3000 15.2998
5. 5 600 497.0315 497.0320 10.1000 10.1002
6. 5 500 477.7025 477.7027 9.6000 9.5999
7. 8 500 521.8831 521.8831 14.0000 13.9999
8. 5 400 472.1799 472.1796 7.8000 7.8000
9. 10 400 546.7347 546.7346 13.0000 13.0004
10. 15 300 577.1088 577.1088 11.3000 11.2996

To predict the hole diameter, the proposed ANFIS possessed 5 Triangular membership functions and 3 Gaussian membership functions respectively, for fuzzification of time and laser power. For modeling the depth of drilled hole, the best modeling results obtained by utilizing 5 membership functions for each of inputs. Figure 7 indicates the membership functions for depth of drilled hole (h) and hole diameter (d). Figure 7.
Membership functions for depth of drilled hole and the hole diameter.

The surface graphs of hole diameter and depth of drilled hole with any of two inputs are shown in Figure 8. It can be seen that the variation of hole diameter with inputs is clearly deliberate. Besides, in both cases, the derived surfaces show smooth variations. Figure 8.
The variation of hole diameter and depth of drilled hole based on input parameters.

sec.title: Scaffold fabrication
sec.p: An optimal scaffold should have the highest amount of strength and porosity and lowest manufacturing time. Since the mechanical strength and porosity are in conflict with each other, it is not feasible to obtain an ideal optimum solution since all the objectives are equally significant. Hence, a set of non-dominated solutions may be produced to trade-off among different objectives.

To obtain the necessary experimental data for identifying the proposed model, three sets of samples with increasing levels of porosity were fabricated. The process parameters and their values are shown in Table 3. These conditions lead to forming a through hole with the hole diameter range of 480 µm and 500 µm according to ANFIS model prediction. Moreover, the calculated porosity (using equation (5)) and the result of compression tests are also presented. Channel size and its center distance are two factors that control the amount of porosity. Table 3.
The fabricated samples.
Sample Laser power (W) (×3.86) Laser irradiation time (ms) Center distance (mm) Porosity (%) Compressive strength (MPa)
1 6.7 500 1 48 52
2 6.7 500 0.875 61 28
3 5.7 500 0.75 75 20

Figure 9 illustrates the fabricated cubic scaffold and its SEM micrograph. According to the SEM image, the channels are interconnected and cylindrical with the diameter range of 500 µm diameter. Three-dimensional and connective network configuration could avail osteogenesis, cell proliferation and it would be expected to provide paths for efficient bone ingrowth. Direct bone formation may also be affected by pore geometry so that longer and curved pores in the scaffolds hinder the penetration of mesenchymal cells and capillaries resulting in bone formation only on the outer surface of the material. Figure 9.
(a) A front view of the fabricated PMMA scaffold, (b) The isometric view, (c) SEM image: 40x, (d) SEM image: 87x show the macro structure of the scaffold with fully interconnected cylindrical channels.

The compression strength of bulk PMMA and PMMA scaffolds were measured using an Instron 4505 mechanical tester (Instron, High Wycombe, England) with a 25 kN load cell. The specimens were bulk cubic with 10 mm edge length. The crosshead speed of the Instron tester was set at 5 mm/min and the load was applied until a 30% reduction in specimen height was achieved. Five samples were tested to obtain the average value. The results show that the less porous scaffolds had better overall properties. Stress–strain data was computed from load–displacement measurements. Results show that porosity greatly affects the compressive strengths of porous PMMA, as can be seen in Figure 10. The compressive strength was decreased remarkably from 150 to 20 MPa as the porosity was increased from 48 to 75. Figure 10.
Effect the compressive strengths of porous PMMA.
Based on the obtained data, the following experimental model is identified. (15)S=0.01Por2-2.8Por+150 where S is mechanical strength (MPa) and Por is the scaffold porosity (%).

Figure 11 shows the optimum relationships between the manufacturing time T compressive strength S and porosity obtained using SOPEA. It can be seen that the proposed method has been converged to true optimal Pareto front and found 245 non-dominated solutions. After a trade-off, a set of solutions with deliberate operational properties have been selected. These solutions are shown in Table 4. Figure 11.
Laser drilling optimal Pareto front.
Figure A.1.
Schematic of ANFIS architecture. Table 4.
The properties of some non-dominated solutions obtained by the proposed SOPEA algorithm.
No. Time (ms) Laser power (W) (/3.86) h (mm) d (mm) Center distance (mm) Porosity (%) Strength (MPa) Manufacturing time (s)
1 320.97 5.93 5.70 0.48 0.844 45.1 25.25 135.05
2 421.63 4.22 6.23 0.42 0.759 46.7 23.40 219.15
3 543.80 3.94 6.23 0.44 0.818 42.5 28.59 243.81
4 320.97 6.49 6.14 0.49 0.844 50.6 19.39 135.05
5 320.97 5.93 5.70 0.48 0.860 43.5 27.30 130.13
6 305.94 9.09 8.07 0.536 0.989 56.0 14.87 93.71
7 347.86 5.36 6.40 0.48 0.949 39.0 33.65 115.72
8 340.41 6.18 6.86 0.50 0.911 48.6 21.40 122.96
9 346.05 6.75 9.86 0.52 0.959 49.8 20.17 112.73
10 434.71 4.22 6.34 0.42 0.759 47.8 22.17 225.95
11 333.66 6.50 6.08 0.50 0.951 44.5 25.96 110.63
12 469.71 4.22 6.68 0.43 0.759 51.8 18.26 244.14
13 460.31 5.8 10.4 0.50 0.912 49.4 20.56 165.89
14 693.85 3.71 5.37 0.43 0.815 37.0 36.78 312.96
15 421.63 4.48 6.88 0.44 0.759 55.4 15.30 219.15

To select the best optimal solution some issues must be taken into consideration. Based on early studies, the minimum requirement for pore size is considered to be ≈100µm due to cell size, migration requirements and transport.29 However, pore sizes >300 µm are recommended, due to enhanced new bone formation and the formation of capillaries. For bone tissue engineering, a scaffold that has relatively large channels (0.5–1 mm) for rapid tissue penetration, is required because large pores, lead to direct osteogenesis.30 Moreover, scaffolds with 3D, highly porous and interconnected structure are fascinated to enhance cell infiltration and mass transport of nutrients and metabolic waste throughout the scaffold. To achieve a 3D fully interconnected structure, all the channels must be drilled through entire height of the scaffold. Among the solutions there is just one solution that satisfies these conditions and yields deliberate operational properties. The properties of this peculiar solution are shown with bold format in Table 4.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, a self-learning evolutionary algorithm was used for optimizing the fabrication process parameters of 3D porous PMMA scaffold fabricated by CO2 laser drilling technique.

First, to predict the geometrical characteristics of drilled holes according to the laser parameters an ANFIS model was developed. The accuracy and effectiveness of developed model was validated by comparing the model output and experimental data. The model illustrated acceptable result in both training and testing phases. Then, based on the model results, three sets of scaffolds with a predefined pattern of channels were produced and tested for mechanical strength. The amount of porosity was also calculated and the influence of porosity on compressive strength was determined. The results showed that the proposed laser drilling process is very helpful and practical in fabricating porous scaffolds as it allows for the fabrication of scaffolds with precise control over pore size by controlling laser parameters. Moreover, channel pattern can be controlled by integrating laser system and computer and the amount of porosity can be predicted based on pore size and center distance. Finally, laser power (p), laser irradiation time (t), and center distance as input parameters were used to estimates three different outputs i.e. manufacturing time, porosity and strength. SOPEA algorithm integrated with SOM was utilized as a supervised optimization technique to find the optimum amount of compressive strength, porosity, and manufacturing time. An optimal scaffold should possess the highest amount of strength and porosity and lowest manufacturing time. After a trade-off, solutions with deliberate operational properties were selected. It is interesting that the optimal solution has moderate level of laser power, laser irradiation time and holes center distance which was unpredictable. The calculated optimal values of the laser power, laser irradiation time and holes center distance are 5.8, 460 and 0.912, respectively.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

GhoreishiMNakhjavaniOB. Optimization of effective factors in geometrical specifications of laser percussion drilled holes. J Mater Proc Tech 2008; 196: 303–310.
SinghRKaintholaASinghTN. Estimation of elastic constant of rock using an ANFIS approach. J Appl Soft Comput 2012; 12: 40–45.
MandaniEHAssilanS. An experiment in linguistic synthesis with a fuzzy controller. Int J Man Mach Stud 1975; 7: 1–13.
TakagiTSugenoM. Fuzzy identification of systems and its applications to modeling and control. IEEE Trans Syst Man Cybern 1985; 15: 116–132.
Jang JSR. Neuro-fuzzy modeling: architecture, analyses and applications. Dissertation, University of California, Berkeley, 1992.
DebK. Multiobjective optimization using evolutionary algorithms, Chichester: John Wiley& Sons Ltd, 2001.

MichalskiRS. Learnable evolution model: evolutionary processes guided by machine Learning. Mach Learn 2004; 12: 269–271.
Amor HB and Rettinger A. Intelligent exploration for genetic algorithms. In: GECCO’05, Washington, 2005, pp. 1531–1538.
KubotaRYamakawaTHorioK. Reproduction strategy based on self-organizing map for genetic algorithms. Int J Innovat Comput 2005; 1: 595–607.

Shah-Hosseini H and Safabakhsh R. TASOM: The time adaptive self-organizing map. In: Proceedings of International Conference of Information Technology: Coding and Computing, Las Vegas, 2000, pp. 422–427.

HulbertSFYoungFAMathewsRS. Potential of ceramic materials as permanently implantable skeletal prostheses. J Biomed Mater Res 1970; 4: 433–456.

sec.title: Appendix
sec.p:
The schematic of ANFIS architecture is indicated in Figure 12. It can be seen that our FIS has two inputs (x,y) and one output(f). The considered rule set with two if–then rules of TSK type of FIS can be mathematically expressed as below.18
Rule 1: if x is A1 and y is B1, then f1=p1x+q1y+r1.
Rule 2: if x is A2 and y is B2, then f2=p2x+q2y+r2. Number of nodes in layer one is related to the number of inputs and the number of membership functions (n) for each of inputs. Number of nodes in layers 2–4 is depends on the number of rules (R) in the fuzzy rule base. The layers of ANFIS are expressed in below.Layer 1
This layer is also known as fuzzification layer. The input Xi is transformed to linguistic labels Aij that represent the membership grade of fuzzy set. The node function of this layer can be defined as: (16)Oij 1=μij (Xi ),i=1,…,numberofinputs, j=1,…,n where μij represents the j-th membership function for the input Xi and Oij 1 is the output of node ij. In this article, the Triangular and Gaussian membership functions are selected based on trial and error. The mathematical formulations of these functions are given by (17)Triangular:μ (X )=max (min (X-ab-a,c-Xc-b ),0 ) where the parameters a and c are locate in the feet of the triangle and the parameter b locates in the peak. (18)Gaussian:μ (X )=exp [- (X-ca )2 ] where a and c is parameter set.Layer 2
This layer is also known as product layer. Each node (k) in this layer is a circle node labeled (∏) that its output is a product of incoming inputs. (19)Ok 2=Wk=μe1 (X1 )μe2 (X2 )…μem (Xm ),k=1,…,R,e1…e2=1,…,n Layer 3
This layer is known as normalized layer. The k-th node determines the ratio of k-th rule’s firing strength to the sum of all rule’s firing strengths. (20)W¯k=WkW1+W2+…+WR,k=1,…,R Layer 4
This layer is known as de-fuzzification layer. Each node in this layer yield the weighted output of the TSK-type FIS as below (21)Ok 4=W¯kfk where W¯k is the output of de-fuzzification layer and fk represents the output of k-th TSK-FIS rule. Here we extend the rule for m input TSK-FIS:
Rule: if (X1 is A1e1) and (X1 is A2e2) and … and (X3 is A3e3) then:
(22)fk=∑i=1 mpiei+rk where (piei, rk) is the parameter set. The parameters in this layer will be referred to as consequent parameters.Layer 5
The last layer is also known as output layer in ANFIS structure. It includes a single labeled encircled (∑) with function of summation. (23)O5=Y=∑k=1 nWk¯fk whereY represents the overall output of the network.
The hybrid algorithm has been allocated to adjust the parameters of both input and output membership functions. During the learning process the performance of ANFIS can be estimated by root mean square (RMS). RMS can be defined as below (24)RMS=∑m=1 n(yp,m-tm,m)2n where n represents the patterns number, yp,m submit the predicted value, tm,m is the measured value of one data point m and tm,m is the mean value of all the measured targets.
